sect2.title: Notices and warnings on arithmetic with invalid strings
sect2.para: New E_WARNING and E_NOTICE errors have been introduced when invalid strings are coerced using operators expecting numbers (+ - * / ** % << >> | & ^) or their assignment equivalents. An E_NOTICE is emitted when the string begins with a numeric value but contains trailing non-numeric characters, and an E_WARNING is emitted when the string does not contain a numeric value.
sect2.informalexample:
<?php
'1b' + 'something';

   
   &example.outputs;
   

Notice: A non well formed numeric value encountered in %s on line %d
Warning: A non-numeric value encountered in %s on line %d

sect2.title: Warn on octal escape sequence overflow
sect2.para: Previously, 3-octet octal string escape sequences would overflow silently. Now, they will still overflow, but E_WARNING will be emitted.
sect2.informalexample:
<?php
var_dump("\500");

   
   &example.outputs;
   

Warning: Octal escape sequence overflow \500 is greater than \377 in %s on line %d
string(1) "@"

sect2.title: Inconsistency fixes to $this
sect2.para: Whilst $this is considered a special variable in PHP, it lacked proper checks to ensure it wasn't used as a variable name or reassigned. This has now been rectified to ensure that $this cannot be a user-defined variable, reassigned to a different value, or be globalised.

sect2.title: Session ID generation without hashing
sect2.para: Session IDs will no longer be hashed upon generation. With this change brings about the removal of the following four ini settings:

session.sid_bits_per_character - defines the number of bits to be stored per character (i.e. increases the range of characters that can be used in the session ID), defaulting to 4 for backwards compatibility

listitem.para: If the value is set to -1, then the dtoa mode 0 is used. The default value is still 14.

sect2.title: Session ID generation with a CSPRNG only
sect2.para: Session IDs will now only be generated with a CSPRNG.

sect2.title: More informative TypeError messages when &null; is allowed
sect2.para: TypeError exceptions for arg_info type checks will now provide more informative error messages. If the parameter type or return type accepts &null; (by either having a default value of &null; or being a nullable type), then the error message will now mention this with a message of "must be ... or null" or "must ... or be null."
